previous.name: The Suffering as Conducive to Extinguishment

segments.en: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.

segments.pli: katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā?
segments.en: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuṃ anattāti passati, rūpā anattāti passati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattāti passati, cakkhusamphasso anattāti passati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattāti passati … pe …
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are not-self. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also not-self.

segments.pli: mano anattāti passati, dhammā anattāti passati, manoviññāṇaṃ anattāti passati, manosamphasso anattāti passati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattāti passati.
segments.en: They see that the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are not-self. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also not-self.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā”ti.
segments.en: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive…

suttaplex.blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as not-self.
